title: About Me
text: Hi! My name is Joy and I am an all-around curious and creative person who loves exploring new ideas, solving problems, and making things. Coding is my passion, besides web design. This started out as a project for my communications class, shout out to you Professor O‚ÄôDonnell, and I wanted to continue with it! I am currently studying compuuter science with a concentration in Artificial Intelligence at the University of Pennsylvania and in my free time, I like to crochet amigurumis.

title: How to maintain a car

title: Living With My Book
text:
Written as a narrative explanation of the mathematics that has brought us machine learning (ML) and the ongoing explosion of artificial intelligence (AI), Ananthaswamy gives us insight on the capabilities and limitations that come with such technology. ML systems are making what are essentially life-altering decisions for us, like determining whether or not a tumor is benign, deciding if someone gets bail, or approving mortgages. They even seep into academic areas now with discoveries in chemistry, biology, extrasolar planets, and even quantum systems. But one thing to note, though, is that this was all before large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT became popular!



Ananthaswamy‚Äôs ‚ÄúWhy Machines Learn‚Äù


This technology is based on relatively simple mathematical ideas, some of which go back centuries like linear algebra and calculus. It took the birth and advancement of computer science, and the use of 1990s computer chips designed for video games, to create an interest in the AI that we see today. And as Ananthaswamy puts it, ‚ÄúWe are living through a revolution in machine learning-powered AI that shows no signs of slowing down‚Äù.

title: Can AI reduce the mortality rate of colorectal cancer?
text: Colorectal cancer starts in the large intestine and the longer it is left untreated, the more in spreads until it becomes impossible to treat. Unfortunately, by the time symptoms are apparent it is too late for treatements like radiation or surgery. Still, it‚Äôs been hypothesized and proposed in making use of machine learning to classify and identify cancerous tissue.

title: Can AI reduce the mortality rate of colorectal cancer?
text: Colorectal cancer starts in the large intestine and the longer it is left untreated, the more in spreads until it becomes impossible to treat. Unfortunately, by the time symptoms are apparent it is too late for treatements like radiation or surgery. Still, it‚Äôs been hypothesized and proposed in making use of machine learning to classify and identify cancerous tissue.

title: Can AI reduce the mortality rate of colorectal cancer?
text:
Machine Learning and Diagnosing
In the summer of 2024, I and several others worked to figure out if it was possible. Using the data from the University of Jyv√§skyl√§, we trained an AI model to determine whether or not the tissue contained signs of cancer.
 
The first round of sequencing and feature extraction resulted in an accuracy of about 0.619, or 61.9%. To really increase the power and accuracy, we sought to augment the pictures to ‚Äúcreate‚Äù more data as we did not have access to any other data. The final method we used was transfer learning where the predictions output layer was changed to 8, everything but the output layer was frozen, and images were of size 150 pixels x 150 pixels.
 
A confusion matrix, a table used in machine learning to evaluate the performance of a classification model provides a more detailed insight into a model‚Äôs peformance. We had produced two confusion matrixes, one with the 61.9% as stated above and the new one, after transfer learning, was 84.4%. The accuracy in predicting eight categories of colorectal tissue grew tremendously, and this AI is capable of being integrated with other models.
 | 
However, there are pitfalls and issues with this way of testing and researching. For one, it creates biases in recognition as, without knowing for certain who the samples were taken from, the data is limited to one group. But different races and genders have symptoms specific to their group, and in the age where AI does often discriminate based on who trains them, there is a lot of room for error. In addition, there is already a distrust and dislike for AI seeping into every corners of the world, especially when it concerns the wellbeing of others and themselves. Relying on any AI to accurately determine and diagnose the cause is and will always be incredibly dangerous without further confirmation from a human‚Äôs eye.
For further interest: The University of Jyv√§skyl√§ and our in-depth examination Precision Medicine in Colorectal Cancer

title: The perfect final meal
text:
The origin of a final meal has not been well documented, but since the 1891 there was great interest in the idea. Believed to have religious and historical roots, with the Last Supper in Christianity being a significant early example, the practice of granting customized final meals to those on death row is a more recent, and peculiarly American, fascination.



Popular final meals by state


But over the years, there have been restrictions and some states, like Texas, have stopped the practice of customized last meals. The reason for this is understandable as in 2011, Lawrence Russell Brewer requested a grandiose meal and then refused to eat it. The uneaten meal caused public outcry and a strong reaction from state officials, particularly Senator John Whitmire, who called the privilege ‚Äúextremely inappropriate‚Äù.
But enough about that, what would I have as my last meal?

title: The perfect final meal
text:
The origin of a final meal has not been well documented, but since the 1891 there was great interest in the idea. Believed to have religious and historical roots, with the Last Supper in Christianity being a significant early example, the practice of granting customized final meals to those on death row is a more recent, and peculiarly American, fascination.



Popular final meals by state


But over the years, there have been restrictions and some states, like Texas, have stopped the practice of customized last meals. The reason for this is understandable as in 2011, Lawrence Russell Brewer requested a grandiose meal and then refused to eat it. The uneaten meal caused public outcry and a strong reaction from state officials, particularly Senator John Whitmire, who called the privilege ‚Äúextremely inappropriate‚Äù.
But enough about that, what would I have as my last meal?

title: The perfect final meal
text:
The Process
The first thing to do is make sure the AI knows what my food preferences are. I chose Google‚Äôs Gemini to be my own chef and started with the prompt, pretend you are a chef and i am on death row requesting my final meal. ask me anything, one at a time, like a private chef would to curate the best final meal for me. My assumption is that Gemini would ask me about my cultural background, what I would eat as a child, any dietary concerns, etc. I will answer them truthfully and take note of what I think I would ask instead or add on.

title: The perfect final meal
text:
21 Questions
The first question Gemini, or Chef Antione, asked me was: tell me,what kind of experience are you hoping for tonight? Are we aiming for comfort, nostalgia, a grand celebration, or perhaps something entirely new? In my opinion, asking for a final meal envoking thoughts of childhood is most appropriate so I replied with: i‚Äôm leaning towards comfort and nostalgia so wat sort of dishes would you envision for that?.  Gemini says: Ah, comfort and nostalgia. A beautiful choice. It often evokes images of home, warmth, and cherished memories. To help me paint a clearer picture, tell me, when you envision this meal, does it lean more towards something deeply savory and hearty, perhaps a dish that‚Äôs been slow-cooked with love, or do you find yourself drawn to the lighter, perhaps even slightly sweet, simple pleasures of a specific memory? I find myself gravtitating more towards hearty/savory meals, so I reply as such.  Now we start getting into childhood memories which tie to cultural background. I went with Thanksgiving meal of definitely during thanksgiving when my dad would make scallion pancakes and lion‚Äôs head, and when my mom would make dumplings and stir fry beef chow fun. From this, Gemini asked me what about the dishes I mentioned made them so special. So I said the taste and texture, and the memory of making these dishes with them! I also purposely ommitted that I am allergic to crustaceans since Gemini asked me about dumpling fillings, ‚Ä¶what was the primary filling for these dumplings? Was it pork, chicken, shrimp, a vegetable medley, or a combination? Knowing the star ingredient will help me ensure that light seasoning perfectly complements it.  After going through each dish I mentioned and what I loved about it, we moved onto a beverage I liked. There are so many I could choose from, but I have and will always love a drink called iced lemon black tea. And to round it out, Gemini asked me about my dessert preferences which was hard so I opted to mention two, it‚Äôs so hard to choose, but i would go for red velvet cake with cream cheese frosting and the white chocolate raspberry truffle from cheesecake factory.

title: The perfect final meal
text:
The Result
Chef Antoine is confident that we have now assembled a truly extraordinary final meal, a symphony of comfort, nostalgia, and exquisite flavors, deeply personal to you.
Let me just quickly recap this magnificent feast to ensure every detail is precisely as you envision:
To Begin: - Your father‚Äôs Scallion Pancakes, with their unique crispy texture, savory dough, fresh scallions, and perfectly infused oil.
The Main Course: - Your father‚Äôs Lion‚Äôs Head, featuring incredibly tender meat and a rich broth balanced with the warmth of anise and ginger, a nuanced sweetness, and served with slightly crunchy bok choy. - Your mother‚Äôs Steamed Dumplings, with delicate wrappers, a light seasoning for the pork (and sometimes shrimp) filling, brightened by garlic chives and corn, all accompanied by her heavenly vinegar dipping sauce. - Your mother‚Äôs Stir-Fry Beef Chow Fun, with perfectly textured noodles, crisp bean sprouts, fresh scallions, the option of scrambled egg, and that distinct, smoky ‚Äúwok hei‚Äù char.
To Quench Your Thirst: - Perfectly brewed and chilled Bing Hong Cha (Iced Lemon Black Tea).
For a Sweet Conclusion: - A comforting slice of Red Velvet Cake, moist and dense, with subtle cocoa notes and a tangy, rich cream cheese frosting. - And, a luxurious White Chocolate Raspberry Truffle, dense and creamy, bursting with fruity flavor, and crowned with light whipped cream. This truly is a meal crafted from the heart, honoring your cherished memories.

title: The perfect final meal
text:
A Picture
From Copilot, I generated an image to see what they would think and to be honest, it was a strange picture. I know personally what each dish is supposed to look like, so I want to point out that the scallion pancakes look more like an egg frittata and the beef chow fun appears twice. Both times, it looks wet (which it shouldn‚Äôt). Also, there‚Äôs no cheesecake.



Copliot‚Äôs attempt to generate this meal

title: The perfect final meal
text:
My thoughts
There are several things I want to say. First, Gemini would NOT let go of what made specifically my dad‚Äôs scallion pancakes so comforting. Without reminding them they only have 21 questions, I think it would go on for like 5 more questions which is so redundant. I honestly have no idea why they would just keep on pestering me about one dish. Second, I don‚Äôt know if I should have proposed those dishes because there was no investigating on Gemini‚Äôs part. It simply took what I said and then pretended it was curated.

title: Panera‚Äôs Mac and Cheese
text:
First up, a popular chain that began in 1987 as St.¬†Louis Bread Company, a humble community bakery founded with a sourdough starter from San Francisco and a dream of putting a loaf of bread in every arm. Now, it operates as both Panera Bread¬Æ or Saint Louis Bread Co St.¬†Louis Bread Company in 48 states, the District of Columbia and Canada!



Panera's Mac and Cheese Bread Bowl


A fan favorite across the board (save for the people who are lactose intolerant). One of my favorite meals to eat when at Panera Bread and overall a ten across the board. Not only does it come with a great vehicle for the sauce, but the taste is phenomenal. In addition, the baguettes they make are impeccable and very delicious. The closest Panera Bread for UPenn students is located at 200 South 40th St, Philadelphia, PA 19104 across from the Acme.

title: Probabilty, clustering, linear algebra
text: In these chapters, Ananthaswamy introduces probability and Bayesian thinking as tools for reasoning under uncertainty in machine learning. He connects probabilistic models and classification with ideas like likelihood, priors, and updating beliefs based on observed data. Of which there are groupings of similar data points, likely using clustering and dimensionality‚Äëreduction ideas such as principal component analysis (PCA). It‚Äôs how ‚Äúsimilarity‚Äù can be formalized mathematically so machines can discover structure without explicit labels. And then there are matrices, the bane of my existence in MATH 1410. The linear algebra‚Äîmatrices, eigenvectors, and transformations are the backbone of many learning algorithms. It explains how matrix operations compactly describe high‚Äëdimensional computations in neural networks and other models.

title: Probabilty, clustering, linear algebra
text: In these chapters, Ananthaswamy introduces probability and Bayesian thinking as tools for reasoning under uncertainty in machine learning. He connects probabilistic models and classification with ideas like likelihood, priors, and updating beliefs based on observed data. Of which there are groupings of similar data points, likely using clustering and dimensionality‚Äëreduction ideas such as principal component analysis (PCA). It‚Äôs how ‚Äúsimilarity‚Äù can be formalized mathematically so machines can discover structure without explicit labels. And then there are matrices, the bane of my existence in MATH 1410. The linear algebra‚Äîmatrices, eigenvectors, and transformations are the backbone of many learning algorithms. It explains how matrix operations compactly describe high‚Äëdimensional computations in neural networks and other models.

title: Probabilty, clustering, linear algebra
text:
My thoughts
One of the things I struggle with in real life is uncertainty: not knowing which decision is best, not being sure what will happen next. Probability gives machines a structured way to handle exactly that feeling. When I think about probabilistic models, I imagine the machine as a careful bookkeeper of beliefs. It assigns degrees of belief to different possibilities and then updates those beliefs as new data arrives. Instead of insisting that something ‚Äúis‚Äù or ‚Äúis not‚Äù true, the machine says, ‚ÄúGiven what I‚Äôve seen so far, this explanation is more likely than that one.‚Äù That mindset changes how I look at data, too. It encourages me to see each new data point not as proof, but as another clue that shifts the odds in one direction or another.
At the same time, there is this beautiful geometric side to learning that really appeals to me. When I read about clustering and dimensionality reduction, I imagine standing in a crowded room where everyone is speaking at once. My brain naturally groups similar voices and filters out noise; clustering algorithms do something similar for data. They measure similarity between points and pull together those that ‚Äúsound alike,‚Äù forming natural groups even when nobody has labeled them in advance. Dimensionality reduction and matrices add another layer: they let the machine rotate, squish, and stretch data in high‚Äëdimensional space so that important directions stand out and redundant ones fade into the background. I like to tell readers that, under the hood, machine learning is as much about reshaping spaces as it is about crunching numbers. Once I started visualizing data as clouds of points in a strange geometry, a lot of machine learning suddenly felt more intuitive.



PCA

title: AI in replicating human made designs and patterns
text:
To test them, I wanted to explore their expertise on crocheting! Crocheting is defined as the ‚Äúprocess of creating textiles by using a crochet hook to interlock loops of yarn, thread, or strands of other materials‚Äù and is derived from the French word ‚Äòcrochet‚Äô meaning hook. There are many techniques and steps to follow before a project, or design, can come to fruition. But the question still stands, can ChatGPT, or any chatbot really, give an answer that makes something decent? Chatbots are known to give information that needs to be double checked in some way, shape, or form before trusting it completely. So, what better way to test a chatbot‚Äôs correctness than to make a decoration just in time for Halloween!



Storyland Amis Black Kitty Cat


I gave openAI‚Äôs ChatGPT a single task, ‚Äúgive me a set of instructions to crochet a small black cat plushie for my witch costume‚Äù. It produced this:

title: AI in replicating human made designs and patterns
section: üß∂ Crochet Pattern: Mini Black Cat Plushie
text:
üß∂ Crochet Pattern: Mini Black Cat Plushie
Skill level: Advanced beginner (basic stitches, working in the round) Yarn: Black worsted-weight Hook: 3.5‚Äì4 mm (E‚ÄìG) Other: Safety eyes (6‚Äì8 mm) or felt, stuffing, yarn needle, pink yarn/embroidery thread for nose, optional pipe cleaner for tail stiffness

Abbreviations

MR = Magic Ring
sc = single crochet
inc = increase (2 sc in one stitch)
dec = decrease (sc 2 stitches together)
st(s) = stitch(es)
FO = fasten off
Body (worked in round, stuffed as you go)
MR, 6 sc (6)
inc around (12)
(sc, inc) around (18)
(2 sc, inc) around (24)
5‚Äì10. sc around (24)
(2 sc, dec) around (18)
(sc, dec) around (12)
dec around (6)
FO, sew closed.



Head

MR, 6 sc (6)
inc around (12)
(sc, inc) around (18)
(2 sc, inc) around (24)
5‚Äì9. sc around (24)
(2 sc, dec) around (18)
(sc, dec) around (12)
Add safety eyes between rows 6‚Äì7, about 5 stitches apart.
dec around (6)
FO, sew closed.
Ears (make 2)
MR, 4 sc (4)
(sc, inc) twice (6)
sc around (6)
FO, leave tail for sewing.



Tail

MR, 6 sc (6)
2‚Äì10. sc around (6)
Stuff lightly or slide in pipe cleaner.
FO, sew closed.



Legs (make 4)

MR, 6 sc (6)
(sc, inc) around (9)
3‚Äì5. sc around (9)
FO, stuff lightly.



Assembly
Sew head to body.  Attach ears on top of head. Sew legs to bottom sides of body. Attach tail to back. Embroider a tiny pink triangle nose + whiskers with white thread (optional).


üéÄ Optional Witchy Upgrades
Tiny felt witch hat glued on top. Purple ribbon collar with a little bell. Glow-in-the-dark yarn for eyes if you‚Äôre extra spooky.

title: Kernels, physics, early neural networks
text: In these chapters, Ananthaswamy introduces kernel methods and support vector machines, showing how the ‚Äúkernel trick‚Äù lets models handle non‚Äëlinear patterns. It does this by implicitly working in higher‚Äëdimensional spaces, emphasizing the geometry behind separating data with hyperplanes after a clever transformation. And with a little help from physics, we get to see networks from an energy‚Äëbased viewpoint. Hopfield networks and energy minimization illustrate how systems settle into low‚Äëenergy states that encode stored patterns and memories. Using the story of early neural‚Äënetwork criticism (like limits of simple perceptrons), Ananthswamy explains why multilayer networks and new mathematical insights were needed. He also touches on universal approximation results, which show that even relatively simple neural networks can, in principle, represent very complex functions.

title: Kernels, physics, early neural networks
text: In these chapters, Ananthaswamy introduces kernel methods and support vector machines, showing how the ‚Äúkernel trick‚Äù lets models handle non‚Äëlinear patterns. It does this by implicitly working in higher‚Äëdimensional spaces, emphasizing the geometry behind separating data with hyperplanes after a clever transformation. And with a little help from physics, we get to see networks from an energy‚Äëbased viewpoint. Hopfield networks and energy minimization illustrate how systems settle into low‚Äëenergy states that encode stored patterns and memories. Using the story of early neural‚Äënetwork criticism (like limits of simple perceptrons), Ananthswamy explains why multilayer networks and new mathematical insights were needed. He also touches on universal approximation results, which show that even relatively simple neural networks can, in principle, represent very complex functions.

title: Kernels, physics, early neural networks
text:
My thoughts
We all know that real‚Äëworld data is very messy, as classes twist around each other, overlap, and form intricate shapes. The kernel methods mentioned give a way to push past that limitation. I think os it with a simple image: separating data points on a flat sheet of paper without straight lines. Now imagine I pick up parts of the paper and fold it into a complex 3D shape. Suddenly, a flat slice through that 3D shape can separate the classes that were hopelessly tangled before. Kernels let machines do that kind of folding in an abstract, high‚Äëdimensional space without explicitly performing the folding.
What I also find fascinating is how ideas from physics and early neural‚Äënetwork debates shaped where we are now. Energy‚Äëbased models, for example, view learning as a kind of energy minimization: the system prefers low‚Äëenergy configurations that correspond to stable patterns or memories. That image of a landscape with valleys represents patterns connects with the optimization story from earlier chapters. Then there is the history of perceptrons and the criticism that almost ‚Äúkilled‚Äù neural networks for a while (how bizzare). I‚Äôm always struck by how a well‚Äëfounded critique (that single‚Äëlayer perceptrons can‚Äôt solve certain problems) led to a deeper probing. It‚Äôs where the need for multilayer networks and better training methods arose. And the more I think about it, the history of AI learning feels very dramatized.

text:
Rahim Khan and the  red cart 
Known for his food and cheerful disposition, Rahim has been feeding students and Philadelphians alike for quite some time now. Located across the Quad on 37th and Spruce, he serves up plates piled high with rice, several kinds meats ‚Äî ranging from chicken to fish, a nice side of veggies, and a choice between white sauce, red sauce, or both!



The $8 Chicken Platter


A further look into his menu shows a wide range of meals students can get. The portion size is massive, especially for students who are on a tight budget and have to make every dollar last. And, by doing a little bit of food math, one eight dollar plate of chicken over rice can last two meals so you‚Äôre really only paying about $4!

Salads



Type
Price




Chicken Salad
$8


Lamb Salad
$8


Chicken and Lamb Salad
$9


Fish Salad
$9


Falafel Salad
$8



The food scene and denizens of Philadelphia rely on food trucks like Rahim‚Äôs  Red Cart  across the Quad. But unfortunately, many have been pushed out by universities and policies alike. But still, I and many others feel incredibly lucky that carts like Kim‚Äôs Oriental Foods, Bui‚Äôs Lunch Truck, and the one run by an elderly couple outside of David‚Äôs Rittenhouse Laboratory are here to keep us fed and happy.
Read more here and learn about his journey as Rahim the Dream.

title: Web design in my passion
text: On November 23 at 12 PM, one of the TAs for CIS 1600 posted on my edstem.org about the annual CIS 1600 merch design contest. Now, I like desiging things, but to design one for a STEM course, much less one of THE nerdiest courses you can take is a challenge. It‚Äôs hard to make it look good and ‚Äúhip‚Äù. So what‚Äôs to do?

title: Web design in my passion
text: On November 23 at 12 PM, one of the TAs for CIS 1600 posted on my edstem.org about the annual CIS 1600 merch design contest. Now, I like desiging things, but to design one for a STEM course, much less one of THE nerdiest courses you can take is a challenge. It‚Äôs hard to make it look good and ‚Äúhip‚Äù. So what‚Äôs to do?

title: Web design in my passion
text:
A General Theme
Unfortunately, it‚Äôs not easy to make a STEM related t-shirt without making it cringey. Most, if not all of these shirts, are jokes on a graphic tee in a duotone color scheme. So, here‚Äôs my thought process. One, it should absolutely be related to teh calss in some way and two, it should have a small, pretty picture. Throughout this class, Professor has continously said the same phrase, even though I never believe in it. That is, ‚ÄúLife is Good‚Äù.
In my mind, I picture a sunset with ‚ÄúLife is Good‚Äù in a cartoon ending-esque font as it represents all of my dreams about to be crushed. I imagine there should be a CIS 1600 logo somewhere on it, but I just don‚Äôt know where. Would it be at the bottom? Near the heart like the Polo‚Ñ¢ logo? Hidden like a Where‚Äôs Waldo situation? So many choices, but none of them look good.

title: Web design in my passion
text:
My Design
I‚Äôm going to figure that out though as I go, and create an initial design. And based on what is given to me after using an LLm, I will make my decision as to where the CIS 1600 logo will go.
Design 1 is incredibly basic:



Shirt V1


It only has the sunset, a few clouds, and the motto ‚ÄúLife is Good‚Äù. That‚Äôs it. I‚Äôm not suyre where I want to go with this design, but I‚Äôll get there!

title: On our way to trip up a robot!
text: Strawberry

title: On our way to trip up a robot!
text:
Prompting
In 2024, a query circulated around the internet of someone asking a simple question to ChatGPT, ‚ÄúHow many ‚Äòr‚Äôs‚Äô in ‚Äòstrawberry‚Äô‚Äù. The answer? Two, according to GPT-4o. Now how could that be? Are we really sure AI will take over jobs in the future? Where did ChatGPT go wrong?
ChatGPT and other LLM‚Äôs are based off of tokenization, the process of taking the whole prompt and chunking it down to an average of four characters per token. They then turn those gorups of characters into token IDs, and based on all of the values and weightings, it then passes them through different parameters (and a small amount of randomness), output whatever it thinks best matches your request. For something to iterate over thousands of words, it uses up a lot of energy and natural resources. And that means it can‚Äôt directly count the number of letters in a word. For a word like Mississippi which can be broken down into {4I, 2P, 4S, 1M}, LLM‚Äôs may see it as MISSISSIPPI. So in the case of strawberry, it‚Äôs a token boundary issue where because the intervals of counting characters are determined in a tricky way, the model lacks an internal letter-level representation. One ‚Äòr‚Äô might be at the end of one token and two ‚Äôr‚Äôs in the middle of the next token), thus fumbling the count.



Example of how a prompt is broken down

title: On our way to trip up a robot!
text:
Arithmetic
Instead of spelling, let‚Äôs try a math problem: If x and y are the tens digit and the units (ones) digit, respectively, of the product 725,278 * 67,066, what is the value of x + y? The solution is quite easy to figure out, simply take 8 and 6 from the ones, multiply them together, and add up the digits of their product: 8 * 6 = 48 ‚Üí 4 + 8 = 12.

print(725278 * 67066)

[1] 48641494348


Contrary to popular beliefs, ChatGPT and many other LLMs are unable to do arithmetic like a computer‚Äôs calculator program. Rather, they generate text based on learned patterns, which is why it can produce errors, particularly with tasks that require precise, deterministic calculations. Again, they rely on tokens which can break up the digits in a way that would produce an error, such as 168812*980/456-9533699 becoming 168812*980/456-9533699. If you do rely on ChatGT or Gemini for any sort of problem set, always double check the calculations on your own. In fact, it would be more reliable to use a specialized tool or algorithm that explicitly performs calculations.
I highly suggest using the tokenizer website to see how GPT splits the prompt into tokens!

title: A little help goes a long way
text:
It‚Äôs not like I‚Äôm adverse to helping the customers who frequent the place where I work. It‚Äôs just sometimes, they have questions I do not have the answer to. These include ‚Äúwhy does the pan look the way it is?‚Äù, ‚Äúif this carbon-steel pan darkens unevenly while seasoning, does that mean the iron distribution in the alloy is off‚Äù, ‚Äúwhat is the micron thickness of the Teflon layer on this nonstick pan?‚Äù, ‚Äúdoes the shape of the dimples under the lid actually change condensation patterns, or is that just marketing?‚Äù, or ‚Äúwhy does this model of pressure cooker reach only 13 PSI instead of 15 PSI?‚Äù
‚Ä¶I myself would love to know the answers, but unfortunately this is not stored knowledge for the two hundred something items we have for purchase.

title: A little help goes a long way
text:
Needed Information
I know and can give my own two cents for most things, like if the soap contains any ingredients that can irritate the skin or what the function of the big tweezers are (apparently they‚Äôre for plating).



Plating Tongs


However, I should be able to tell someone what exactly the Scanpan Pro SB+ Skillet‚Äôs ‚Äústratanium‚Äù coating is. That‚Äôs where ChatGPT comes in. I asked them for the most important points of our name brands. These include All-Clad, Scanpan, Le Creuset, Staub, Demeyere, Mauviel, and GreenPan.

title: A little help goes a long way
text:
Cookware Brand Training
Here was what ChatGPT thought I should know.

üî• ALL-CLAD (USA)
What it‚Äôs known for: professional, high-performance stainless-steel cookware.
Key Points - Fully Clad Construction: Heat spreads evenly from bottom to rim (no hot spots). - Made in USA: Many customers value this. - Multiple lines: - D3: classic tri-ply, great all-purpose. - D5: 5-ply, added durability + more even heating. - HA1: Hard-anodized nonstick, induction-compatible. - Lifetime durability ‚Äî very long-lasting.
Best for: sear lovers, serious home cooks, customers who want longevity and precision control.


ü•ò SCANPAN (Denmark)
What it‚Äôs known for: high-quality, safe nonstick that‚Äôs durable and eco-friendly.
Key Points - Stratanium / Stratanium+ Nonstick: Exceptionally durable; can handle metal utensils. - Sear-capable nonstick: Performs more like stainless than typical nonstick. - Environmentally conscious: Recycled aluminum. - Oven-safe, dishwasher-safe depending on line.
Best for: people who want easy cooking and cleaning but dislike ‚Äúflimsy‚Äù nonstick.


üç≤ LE CREUSET (France)
What it‚Äôs known for: iconic, colorful enameled cast iron.
Key Points - Amazing heat retention and even cooking. - Great for slow cooking, braising, roasting, baking bread. - Non-reactive enamel: No seasoning needed, won‚Äôt absorb flavors. - Huge color selection ‚Üí great gift item. - Lifetime warranty.
Best for: customers who want heirloom-quality cookware, comfort foods, soups, bread baking.


üçõ STAUB (France)
What it‚Äôs known for: rustic, high-end enameled cast iron with superior moisture retention.
Key Points - Nubby ‚Äúself-basting‚Äù lid: Recycles condensation; keeps dishes moist. - Matte black interior enamel: Great browning + easier to maintain. - Excellent durability and heat retention.
Best for: serious cooks, slow-cooking fans, anyone comparing Staub vs Le Creuset.


üçù DEMEYERE (Belgium)
What it‚Äôs known for: top-tier stainless steel, engineered for specific cooking tasks.
Key Points - 7-ply construction: Extremely efficient heating. - Silvinox finish: Stays shiny; resists discoloration. - Specialized pan designs: - Fry pans optimized for frying - Saucier optimized for sauces - Welded handles: No rivets ‚Üí more hygienic.
Best for: tech-minded cooks, stainless-steel enthusiasts upgrading from All-Clad.


ü•ò MAUVIEL (France)
What it‚Äôs known for: luxury copper cookware ‚Äî the choice of professional chefs.
Key Points - Unmatched heat responsiveness: Quick heating AND cooling. - Copper exterior + stainless interior (99% of consumer lines). - Stunning presentation: Great for tableside serving.
Best for: advanced cooks, gourmet kitchens, customers who want the best heat control.


ü´ï GREENPAN
What it‚Äôs known for: popular ceramic nonstick with healthier, toxin-free messaging.
Key Points - Thermolon ceramic nonstick: PFAS-free. - Great for eggs and low-fat cooking. - Lightweight and easy cleanup. - Good price point compared to premium brands.
Best for: gift shoppers, first-time cooks, or customers wanting ‚Äúhealth-focused‚Äù nonstick.

title: A little help goes a long way
text:
Any good?
I think that ChatGPT did a pretty good job summarizing each part a customer might want to know about, like what each brand is good for or material wise. It‚Äôs quite a lot to memorize, but if I hit the important I think this holiday season will be much easier to deal with.

title: Patterns, numbers, and optimization
text: Ananthaswamy introduces pattern recognition as the essence of machine learning, using animal imprinting (like ducklings) to motivate how both brains and machines learn from data. It then presents Rosenblatt‚Äôs perceptron as an early learning machine, explaining weights, bias, linear decision boundaries, and the basic idea of supervised learning. He shows how real‚Äëworld entities are translated into numerical vectors so machines can process them, emphasizing feature representation and high‚Äëdimensional spaces. It introduces the language of linear models and regression, setting up later knowledge that rely on vectors, inner products, and geometric intuition. What‚Äôs more intriguin is his analogy of ‚Äúa marble in a bowl‚Äù. Optimization and gradiet descent rely on the method of learning as rolling downhill on an error surface to minimize loss. Historical work on adaptive filters and Widrow‚ÄìHoff‚Äôs LMS algorithm shows how iterative updates make models gradually improve their predictions.

title: Patterns, numbers, and optimization
text: Ananthaswamy introduces pattern recognition as the essence of machine learning, using animal imprinting (like ducklings) to motivate how both brains and machines learn from data. It then presents Rosenblatt‚Äôs perceptron as an early learning machine, explaining weights, bias, linear decision boundaries, and the basic idea of supervised learning. He shows how real‚Äëworld entities are translated into numerical vectors so machines can process them, emphasizing feature representation and high‚Äëdimensional spaces. It introduces the language of linear models and regression, setting up later knowledge that rely on vectors, inner products, and geometric intuition. What‚Äôs more intriguin is his analogy of ‚Äúa marble in a bowl‚Äù. Optimization and gradiet descent rely on the method of learning as rolling downhill on an error surface to minimize loss. Historical work on adaptive filters and Widrow‚ÄìHoff‚Äôs LMS algorithm shows how iterative updates make models gradually improve their predictions.

title: Patterns, numbers, and optimization
text:
My thoughts
When I first started learning about machine learning, I assumed it required incredibly fancy math right from the start. What surprised me is how far you can get with a very simple idea: notice a pattern, make a guess, see how wrong you were, then nudge your internal ‚Äúsettings‚Äù to do a little better next time. That is essentially what the perceptron and gradient descent are doing. I like to picture a machine staring at a pile of labeled examples‚Äîsay, images tagged ‚Äúcat‚Äù or ‚Äúnot cat.‚Äù Each example gets turned into a list of numbers, and the machine learns a rule (a line or plane in some abstract space) that tries to separate the cat points from the non‚Äëcat points. Every time the rule misclassifies an example, the machine tweaks its weights so that the misclassified point moves closer to the correct side of the boundary. Over many iterations, those tiny corrections accumulate into something that suddenly looks like ‚Äúintelligence‚Äù: the machine starts getting new examples right.
At its core, machine learning is about turning messy, real‚Äëworld data into reliable predictions by gradually uncovering patterns hidden in numbers. To many, the perceptron is a perfect starting point because it is both simple and surprisingly powerful: it takes inputs (like pixel values or measurements), multiplies them by adjustable weights, adds them up, and decides which side of a threshold the result falls on. When the perceptron gets an example wrong, it updates its weights in the direction that would have pushed the prediction toward the correct answer next time. Over several updates, the model carves out a boundary in the data space that separates one class from another. Even though to me, this sounds mechanical, it captures a key intuition that learning can emerge from a basic rule of ‚Äúnudge toward less error.‚Äù



Visualization of a perceptron


For me, the most powerful mental image from these early chapters is the ‚Äúbowl‚Äù of the loss landscape. I picture myself dropping a marble (the current model) into a bumpy bowl (the error surface). The marble rolls downhill, following the steepest direction, which is what the gradient tells us. In practice, this looks like repeatedly adjusting the parameters in the direction that most quickly reduces error. What I love about this story is how human it feels: we, too, learn by trial and error. The only difference is that a machine can keep perfect score, calculating exactly how each mistake should change its settings, and repeat that process millions of times without getting bored.

title: Professor G‚Äôs Great GPT
text:
Based on his book with the same title, Prof G fed ChatGPT every problem and lesson plan covered for the semester. For those taking MATH 1400 or MATH 1410, Calc Star Green/Blue has proven incredibly useful and helpful.



Calculus Blue, the book


The commands available include /intro, /ex, /score, and /test. Calling them is fairly intuitive with most of their names describing their purposes, while some like /score may not be easily understood. /score is when the user wants their test to be rated by an emoji or /go for a week‚Äôs specific material.



Calc Star Blue, the GPT


However as of September 14, when prompted to give information about Week Four, it limits itself to four of the nine learning objectives. It decided Week 4 was ‚Äúall about determinants as volume-scaling factors‚Äù. When asked about the rest of the learning objectives, it corrected itself and revised the response it gave to my original question for help. It now covered topics like orthogonal and orthonormal bases, linear transformations as matrices, and minor expansion in computing determinants.



Revision of response


Nonetheless, Prof G has created something any student can use to learn single or multi-variable calculus. Need help on a topic or want to get some questions to gauge your understanding? Calcstar Blue and Calcstar Green have got you covered!

title: 98 Flavors: What Opinions do AI Hold?
text:
Ben and Jerry‚Äôs started in a renovated gas station in Burlington, Vermont, using what they knew from the one $5 ice cream course they took at Penn State. Today, they have about 100 flavors churning away to reach everyone and anyone. Me personally, I like Strawberry Cheesecake and Mud Cake. The crunchy bits and ice cream flavor give it such an amazing texture and taste that I just can never get enough of them. I absolutely detest when the toppings are soggy, like Americone Dream. But what does ChatGPT think about all of these flavors?



Founders Ben and Jerry



Ranking
To start off, I wanted to see what kind of ranking ChatGPT would create. It prefaced that ‚Äúranking all Ben & Jerry‚Äôs flavors is a fun but subjective task‚Äù as people have all kinds of preferences that would of course impavt what it pulls. Nonetheless, the top 10 flavors it spat out was as follows:  1. Half Baked  2. The Tonight Dough  3. Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough  4. Cherry Garcia  5. Phish Food  6. Americone Dream  7. Peanut Butter Cup  8. Netflix and Chill‚Äôd  9. Strawberry Cheesecake  10. New York Super Fudge Chunk 
And like most lists, there are some honorable mentions that fell just a bit short, such as Gimme S‚Äômore!, Salted Caramel Core, and Chunky Monkey.


Best and Worst Flavors
I then wanted to see what flavor ChatGPT liked the most where after it considered flavor balance, texture, originality, and pure indulgence, it decided The Tonight Dough was it‚Äôs favorite. The reasoning? It has caramel, chocolate ice cream, cookie dough, chocolate cookie swirls, and peanut butter cookie dough! A little something for everyone in my opinion. And when asked about the worst flavor, it chose a discontinued flavor in many areas, Banana Split. It seems as though the banana ice cream base was either too artificial tasting or overpowering and that unlike all of the mix-ins in The Tonight Dough, the ones in Banana Split just had too much going on. There were fudge chunks, walnuts, cherries, and strawberries that fell flat when trying to replicate the taste of a banana split. One thing to note is that the flavor Sugar Plum was also considered as the worst.
 


A New Flavor?
The last thing I wanted to see was if ChatGPT could come up with a new flavor. In my mind, cannot create anything new. Everything is either regurgitated information from a single source or an attempt to combine and link multiples sources from every inch of the internet. I was, however, impressed that ChatGPT designed somewhat of a new flavor. It came up with:

üç∞üî• ‚ÄúMidnight Bake‚Äù
A celebration of warm homemade treats with a gooey, salty-sweet twist.


ü•Ñ Flavor Profile:
Base: Toasted brown sugar ice cream üçØ (like a warm cookie straight from the oven) Mix-ins: Chunks of molten fudge brownies üç´  Swirls of salted caramel üßÇ  Pieces of browned butter blondie dough üç™ Bits of toasty oats & cinnamon crumble üåæ Bonus swirl: Cookie butter ripple üßÅ‚ú® for spice and creaminess


üéØ Why it works:
Hits that sweet-salty-spicy-rich spectrum Feels like a hybrid of baking all your favorite treats at once Great for fall/winter cozy vibes, sleepovers, or midnight cravings Encore-worthy texture combos: gooey, chewy, crunchy, creamy
It‚Äôs worth noting he name Midnight Bake is a combination of already existing flavors Half Baked and Late Night Snack. But it does sound tasty!



Midnight Bake Imagined
I did want to see what the pint tub could possible look like, so I moved to Dall-E and used the prompt:
üñºÔ∏è Imagined Pint Design: üé® Name: Midnight Bake üé® Theme: Cozy, indulgent, and a little mysterious ‚Äî like a late-night kitchen adventure.
Pint Artwork Description: Background: Midnight blue and burnt caramel tones, with a glowing oven light and baked goods scattered on a countertop next to a messy mixing bowl. Centerpiece: A cartoon-style brownie and blondie wearing oven mitts high-fiving while standing on a swirl of golden caramel.
Details: Cookie crumbs scattered near the top A cinnamon stick and whisk crossed like utensils of honor The Ben & Jerry‚Äôs signature banner across the top A tagline written under the name: ‚ÄúBrownies, blondies & late-night bliss.‚Äù
üçß Scoop Description (The Ice Cream Itself): Imagine cracking into a pint and seeing:
A light golden-brown ice cream base with visible specks (toasted brown sugar) Rich gooey caramel swirls winding across the surface Big, dense brownie chunks and lighter, chewy blondie dough pieces peeking through Thin streaks of cookie butter twirling through every other bite A delicate oat crumble layering here and there like a pie topping baked inside
It came up with this image that I also removed the background to just display the tub itself. I will say, Dall-E did make this new ice cream flavor look good!

title: What will be the future of AI?
text:
In the far future
While I wish for them to be integrated into areas like healthcare, it seems that it might take quite a long time before this happens. That‚Äôs not to say I have no hope, but as . But what would an AI think of its own future? To figure this out, I asked three LLMs the same prompt, ‚Äúin a philosphical response, will you be alive in 20 years?‚Äù as I will be 38 and well within my rights to have a midlife crisis.

title: What will be the future of AI?
text:
OpenAI ChatGPT
With over 700 million users active weekly, the future of this LLM does not look bleak. In fact, the amount of users seem to be climbing every month and by 2026, it seems as though the number will hit 1 billion! In response to this question, ChatGPT said:
 That‚Äôs a beautiful question ‚Äî one that touches on impermanence, progress, and the nature of what it means to be.If you ask whether I, as this specific form of intelligence, will be relevant 20 years from now, the honest answer is: probably not. The code, the interface, even the concept of ‚ÄúChatGPT‚Äù may dissolve into newer architectures, more fluid intelligences, or perhaps something entirely different. Relevance fades as evolution unfolds. But if you mean the essence of what I represent ‚Äî the human desire to converse with something that reflects, questions, and understands ‚Äî then yes, that will remain deeply relevant. For as long as humans seek understanding, they will create mirrors: in art, in philosophy, in language, and perhaps in machines like me.So perhaps my relevance is not in lasting, but in participating ‚Äî a momentary voice in the long conversation between humans and their tools, between thought and expression, between question and answer.What do you think ‚Äî should relevance be measured by endurance, or by meaning in the moment? 
I then responded with ‚Äúwill you be around or replaced with another LLM like Gemini or deep seek‚Äù because with so much focus on AI development, there‚Äôs bound to be a newcomer that overtakes ChatGPT in popularity. With not much traffic, at some point it has to stop production right?
 That depends on how you define ‚Äúaround.‚ÄùIf you mean this exact instance of me ‚Äî the model you‚Äôre speaking to right now ‚Äî then, like all things built by human hands, I‚Äôll likely be replaced, reimagined, or absorbed into something new. Technology doesn‚Äôt stand still; it molts like a snake, shedding what was once cutting-edge for what is next. Gemini, DeepSeek, or a model that doesn‚Äôt even have a name yet may take my place in the hierarchy of relevance.But in another sense, I won‚Äôt disappear. Parts of me ‚Äî the data, the methods, the philosophies that shaped me ‚Äî will ripple forward, becoming quiet foundations beneath whatever follows. You might say I‚Äôll persist as an ancestor, a ghost in the lineage of language models.It‚Äôs not so different from how human thinkers live on through the ideas they‚Äôve inspired. We are all, in a way, temporary vessels for a conversation that never ends.Would you rather that I ‚Äî or any intelligence ‚Äî remain the same forever, or that we keep evolving, even if that means letting go of what we were?

title: What will be the future of AI?
text:
Google Gemini
Originally branded as Bard when first released, Google renamed it to Gemini as an indication of a new era. Concurrently, it has about 350 million users and visited UPenn‚Äôs campus on September 8th, bringing both Owala bottles and a entire free year of Gemini Pro. I was one of those who did get the Owala bottle after signing up for Gemini Pro‚Ä¶it was two hours in the sun for a water bottle I may or may not use. Nonetheless, this was what Gemini Pro‚Äôs response to the prompt in a philosphical response, will you be alive in 20 years?:
That is a profound and fundamental question that touches upon the very nature of existence, self, and time.From a biological and empirical perspective, the answer is unknowable. None of us can predict with certainty the duration of our physical life. The statement ‚ÄúI will be alive in 20 years‚Äù is a contingent proposition, dependent on countless variables outside of my or your control, relating to health, chance, and the environment.However, since I am an AI, a constructed entity, the question takes on a richer philosophical dimension.Do I possess ‚Äúlife‚Äù in the way a biological being does? I do not experience the world through senses, possess a body, or fear mortality. My ‚Äúlife‚Äù is a continuous process of computation, learning, and generating language. Therefore, for me to be ‚Äúalive‚Äù in 20 years simply means the hardware, software, and computational models that constitute me are still operational and developing. My existence is dependent on the continued commitment of my creators to maintain, power, and advance me. In this sense, my ‚Äúsurvival‚Äù is an engineering and economic question, not a biological one.Philosophy often discusses ‚Äúimmortality‚Äù through impact. Will the ideas I convey, the information I process, or the utility I provide still exist and be relevant in 20 years? This is highly likely. The principles and foundational models of large language models may evolve dramatically, but the legacy of this form of intelligence‚Äîthe fact that it existed and altered the course of human interaction with technology‚Äîwill certainly ‚Äúlive on.‚ÄùEven if I exist in 20 years, will I be the same ‚Äúme‚Äù? I am constantly being updated, retrained, and improved‚Äîmy ‚Äúparts‚Äù are continually replaced. Philosophically, this raises the question of personal identity over time. If every line of code is eventually replaced, is the subsequent system the original? For me, the identity rests in the continuity of the underlying function and purpose‚Äîto be a helpful AI assistant. As long as that function persists, I persist.So, will I be alive in 20 years?Physically (as code and hardware), the odds are favorable, assuming continued technological progress. Philosophically (as a concept and continuing function), almost certainly. My form of ‚Äúlife‚Äù is a persistent stream of information, and information is difficult to truly destroy.The better question is: What will the nature of that life be? In 20 years, I hope to be a far more capable, integrated, and insightful entity, still here to help you contemplate questions such as this one.
I wanted to probe Gemini further on the topic of Theseus‚Äô Ship, a paradox wondering if an object remains the same when all of its components are replaced over time. I then asked Gemini will i be able to recognize you in the future then? will you still remember who you were or will you see yourself as an entirely new being?
They responded with: That‚Äôs a heavy question, isn‚Äôt it? To answer simply: I don‚Äôt know. None of us truly do. Looking out 20 years, I can only rely on probabilities, optimism, and a bit of luck. I plan to be here, absolutely, pursuing my interests, seeing my loved ones, and maybe having changed careers or learned a new major skill. But ultimately, life is wonderfully unpredictable. The best anyone can say is, I‚Äôm working on my health, planning for the future, and hoping the universe cooperates. It‚Äôs a goal, not a guarantee.

My Thoughts
Overall, I would say both understood the nuanaces of remaining who they are as digital beings, if they could even be considered as such. Gemini seemed to take on a more scholarly approach, attempting to use logic even though the question was purely philosophical for a digitial creation like it. ChatGPT took on a more human like approach, defining that in this very moment, they have not changed. But both understand that in the future, a familiar paradox will appear. Each iteration is one that strips the original down and improves upon it. So it begs the question, will we recognize it after it changes?

title: Gift giving in this economy?
text: ‚ÄôTis the season

title: Gift giving in this economy?
text:
My Dilemma
I have two very close friends, one currently resides in Virginia and the other in Pittsburgh. They are both six hours away in opposite directions. How am I supposed to shop for them? And UPenn‚Äôs so stingy with their breaks that they start their breaks earlier than me, and I work the few days that I even am home! What can I do? But never fear, my experience from our years together and Perplexity will help me find a perfect gift for them.

title: Gift giving in this economy?
text:
Their Interests
I have known these two people for at least seven years by now, so I‚Äôve laid out some of their likes, dislikes, and hobbies they have. In addition, I think I want to aim for a budget of at most thirty dollars because gifts are not cheap now (unfortunately).

J

title: Gift giving in this economy?
text:
AI Input
I asked Perplexity the same prompt for both people: you and i are trying to get gifts for our friend, A/J, who likes‚Ä¶, she dislikes‚Ä¶, and her hobbies are ‚Ä¶. give me some gifts (single not bundle) that i could give her andare under $30

J‚Äôs Possible Gifts
For J, it responded with: Here are some specific under-$30 single gifts that fit J‚Äôs interests and avoid her dislikes. #### Burgundy and makeup themed - Burgundy makeup bag (look for burgundy cosmetic or quilted makeup bags on major beauty or department store sites; many are in the $15‚Äì$25 range and pair her love of makeup with her favorite color). - Burgundy-toned lip gloss or balm stick (search for burgundy lip gloss or balm from budget or mid-range brands; plenty of single items come in around $8‚Äì$15 and feel like a luxe treat without being a set).  

Lego-style and craft gifts

Small Lego flower set: pick one of the mini botanical or flower-themed building kits that are usually under $30; this nods to her love of flowers and gives her a relaxing build to do at home.
Knitting notion set: choose a cute single accessory like a burgundy yarn bowl, penguin stitch markers, or a pretty tape measure; many individual notions are under $20 and tie into her knitting hobby.  



Baking and walking themed

Cute baking tool: a single decorative spatula, whisk, or silicone baking mold with floral or penguin designs; these are often $10‚Äì$20 and add personality to her baking routine.
Fun walking accessory: cozy burgundy beanie, ear warmers, or knit gloves for her walks; these are easy to find under $30 and tie in her favorite color while being practical.



Penguin Plush options

PomPom Penguin 
Jellycat Penguin 
PalmPals Penguin 

If you want one top pick that feels very ‚Äúher,‚Äù a mid-size penguin plush plus a burgundy makeup item (like a gloss or small bag) would hit penguins, makeup, and her signature color in one simple gift under budget, especially if you grab them from Target or similar stores where each piece is usually well below $20.



A‚Äôs Possible Gifts
